page.title: 01General Description of Block
page.content: This block is in the Weald of Kent, ten miles south of Maidstone. Kent is sometimes called the "Garden of England" and this especially applies to our area. The main ground useage in our block is crop growing, mainly rape and corn. There are many orchards and some traditional Kent hops in the area. There are a lot of dew ponds caused by the clay soil. It is a flat area only varying between 20 and 30 metres above sea level over all twelve squares. There are quite a few traditional Kentish farms and there is a farm museum.There is light industry and craft such as coppicing at West End Cottage and Cockle Wood. Two of the squares contain part of the village Staplehurst and the tower of its parish church can be seen from any of the squares in the block.
